title: @Riot: Why do you have such motivation to change your game?
body:
**I'd like to begin by quoting a certain Thomas Bertram Lance: "If it ain't broke, don't fix it."
**

League of Legends is an undeniable and irrefutable success of a game. League has cultivated a motivated and serious competitive playerbase. League has contributed to the rise of esports in the civilized world to the point where I have seen video game highlights on weekend ESPN. I've heard it said that North America has more unique League accounts than baseball players (from MLB all the way down through little league). League, as a game, is a huge success.

**So then, why is there such motivation to change the winning formula?
**

For almost five full years, there were very few major changes to the fundamentals of League of Legends. Yes, there were changes. Dodge chance didn't last very long, for example. Champions were tweaked and nerfed or buffed. Some items came and went. Artwork was updated. New champions were added. Nevertheless, these changes never felt like they changed the fundamental way that League of Legends was played. Even amidst the meta changes, It had always been the same game. That same game was, again, an undeniable and irrefutable success.

**So then why change what has worked?
**

Change is necessary and natural and in many cases good. The fundamentals really changed first with the jungle: items/smite grew diverse, new camps/buffs were added. The S5 jungle changes were the first time it really felt like we needed to "relearn" how to play parts of the game. The echoes (pun intended) of that single fundamental change are still being felt; devourer has only recently been removed.

**Think about how many other major changes have been introduced in the past calendar year:
**
Juggernauts
ADC reworks
Vision changes
Jungle timers
Death timers
New baron, dragon, herald buffs
Ranked queues
Champion select
Now, the Mage reworks

I'm sure there are some others that are missing and others can correct me below. Every single one of these changes has affected the fundamental way that a League game is played. I've even seen the argument that Revive would be a valuable summoner spell, should it be reintroduced, because of the new death timers.

**@Riot: Why are you so adamant about changing your game in major ways? What is the underlying motivation to change, rather than preserve, the formula that won you so much acclaim?**

It feels like you've spent half a decade creating the perfect chocolate chip cookie recipe. Sure, you've changed some things - an extra pinch of sugar, a slight adjustment of chips to dough ratio, the occasional nut or dark chocolate addition, but it's still a chocolate chip cookie and a damn good one at that. Season 6 though... it's like you're dumping in coconut and nutmeg and chili powder and caviar and all these new things. Meanwhile, you're telling us that your data supports your changes and that your product is going to be better because of it.

All I want is a goddamn chocolate chip cookie... and the fundamental League of Legends that got me here in the first place. It's the same shape as before, but it feels like a different game altogether.

replies.body: Because winning formulas are often winning because they are innovative not stagnant.

This is a great point and one with which I agree.

League has always been innovative, but gradually. This gradual innovation contributed to the undeniable success of League.

The trouble is that innovative isn't the right word anymore. Innovative is rearranging your furniture and adding a new wallpaper. Season 6 is throwing the furniture away and tearing down a wall and making a new room altogether.

sorry but I do not agree with that definition of innovation. Repackaging the same thing is only innovative the first time, it can be refreshing but it is not innovative, that would be like making a numbers patch and then reverting it over and over and calling it innovation. Innovation does not require tearing down the old and tearing down the old does not mean that something is innovative, but without add/refining mechanics/items/abilities you cannot have innovation. You could argue that they should slow down the rate of change so that they don't leave people to far behind but not to stop.


In my opinion they are changing things at a good pace, there are very large changes but they are also localized changes so we can know what to expect. I say these large changes are acceptable because it consists of many similar smaller changes ie the Mage Rework or Marksmen Update.

To use the cookie analogy, chocolate chip is great and all, but even if they change the recipe every once in a while you're going to get tired of them after a few years. If you want to stay in the cookie business you're going to have to figure out how to fill an entire variety box, and unless you're stealing someone else's recipes for all the other types of cookies, there's going to be a new excess of trial and error involved. Other people need to taste test these new cookies after all, and it's inevitable not all of the recipes are going to get rave reviews.

The only thing I want to point out about the anology here, is that people add more flavors. A big cookie bussiness that wants another flavor isn't going to just stop making the cookies that got them there in the first place, they add to the list of flavors. So it doesn't really fit in the the context of a video game because a video game can only take one cookie flavor at a time, while the cookie producers can make multiple flavors.
exactly. chips ahoy didnt say "fuck u, we know whats better for u all, heres peanut butter cookies and thats the only thing were gona make. we know youll buy them , youre addicted"

> 
> 
> In my opinion they are changing things at a good pace, there are very large changes but they are also localized changes so we can know what to expect. I say these large changes are acceptable because it consists of many similar smaller changes ie the Mage Rework or Marksmen Update.

Well, innovation comes with risks and requires to start with a good risk estimation as well as a recovery plan. If something goes wrong, you must minimize the damage done and focus on fixing the problem.

Adding more changes for the sake of innovation before the previous changes have stabilised are going to lead to a disastrous situation where fixing anything will be nothing short of a nightmare.

In the end innovation is good, necessary even, but needs to be controlled and carefully planned.

My personal opinion is that too many changes have been pushed before stabilising the state of the game. This makes LoL feel like a very different game. Some will like it, some won't.

> [{quoted}](name=UberAffe,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=ZKVYf4NB,comment-id=0001,timestamp=2016-05-09T21:05:16.611+0000)
>
> Because winning formulas are often winning because they are innovative not stagnant.

Oh really?! 
How much has soccer, basketball or any other major international sport changed over the decades?
Do you honestly believe they would have enjoyed the same popularity if they were being handled the same way Riot handles League?

"Often" and your examples are cases of tradition, they have been around in their current form for so long that people wouldn't even know how to change them anymore. Even so I know I might actually show some interest in traditional sports if someone threw a wrench in the mix. 

Actually even with my limited knowledge of traditional sports they seem to undergo almost the same levels of change as league is. In league and those sports the win conditions haven't changed but the techniques(playstyles) have changed. When these sports started there were no "Professionals" there were just people who happened to be good and made a team. It wasn't a career before. That change was massive and changed what people expected from theses sports. If that change had never happened I don't think people would care nearly as much.

A concrete example of other major changes would be curved blades on sticks in hockey. It used to be illegal to use a curved blade but that rule got changed, which literally changed how the game was played. It changed when people could pass, how far away they could shoot from, even how fast they could skate with the puck. That is at least as large a change to hockey as these changes to league are.

No sport is as inherently complicated as League. Additionally, sports have different roles but they don't have 130+ champions that are sorted into those roles in addition to player skill/knowledge disparity. They just have the players.

Edit: Basketball added the 3-point shot a few decades ago and has made other rule changes on a semi-regular basis. Other sports have also changed their rules, though no other one that I can think of has had that kind of impact.

When rules for sports change, its because a player performance shows that things need to be changed. Rules need to be made specifically because of those players. 

Riot making changes to prevent Proxy Singed from being a free win is a good parallel to that, not the changes they've been trying to push forward the past year.

Traditional sports are too ingrained in society to easily fall out of favor.  Not to mention each season can be widely different from the previous thanks to players and staff being reorganized and some moving from one team to another pretty regularly.  

LoL doesn't have the luxury of being so ingrained in society that they can regulate themselves to minor changes and still draw new crowds.  Eventually it would become formulaic and people would start to walk away due to boredom.

While it's system isn't perfect, Riots working to try and keep things always fresh and new in League.  Jeremy "Gaming Curios" and Extra credit both refer to this as Perfect Imbalance.  Granted, I'm stretching a little adhering that title to the massive changes Riot makes.  I do feel though that it fits the description.

They didn't change things for a long time, outside of relatively minor tweaks each preseason, and were only getting more popular. 

What you're saying would make sense if season 6 never happened.

That falls to a different matter.  For a long time Riot apparently didn't know what direction they wanted to take LoL in.  Then apparently sometime in season 5 they finally decided what route they wanted to take the game in and have been pushing towards that.

I'd try looking up the red posts that point to this, but good grief, it's probably buried under a mountain by now.
I believe this was actually in Season 4 that they stated they were going for a specific goal with the game but it only started making itself apparent by Season 5.

Preseasons 3 4 and 5 were fairly large changes to the game. While pre and midseason 6 have had bigger changes on the whole, things such as the jungle and itemization have always gone through major overhauls alongside major changes to the ranked system itself in that time because Riot would hold off on these changes in the build up to worlds.
Rules can change simply for a perceived benefit to the sport too. That is what happened with curved blades in hockey.

Hockey is also a pretty casual sport in the sense that there are not many technical fouls that are not safety related; relative to other sports, at least.  

Its a pretty open-ended game, unlike just about every other sport, which are all slathered with rules and regulations. 

Hockey is more of an exception among static rule sets than a great example of how dynamic rules are in sports.

This is actually the reason I believe LoL E-Sports will never be the "American Pasttime" that Riot has delusions about it being.  Aside from the enormous learning curve and the never ending introduction of new champions (which continually steepens the learning curve), there are WAY too many changes for it to ever be considered a traditional sport like baseball or soccer.  We've only had 5 seasons and the game has been changed and tweaked to oblivion.  It's drastically different from when it first began.  Can you imagine in 20 years, if league is even still around, what it would look like?  It probably wouldn't even look like League anymore.  You probably wouldn't even be able to recognize it.  And that's why it will never be adopted as or considered a traditional sport.  Just stop trying to make your pipe dream happen, Riot.  Stop balancing the game around the 0.1% of pro/competetive players and just go back to the way the game was years ago so it can maybe be fun again for the millions rather than the hundreds.
implying that Riot hasn't balanced around diamond, challenger, and the pro season since the beginning of it...

tell me again about the diverse champion pool in soccer, and the purchaseable items available to everyone that affect your stats. tell me about all the ways you can change the variables of the game as a player that aren't related to your skill. Tell me about how that game develops new strategies.

League is WAY, WAY, WAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAY more complex than a game like Soccer, and as a result it can't just be "left alone". Games like soccer and football don't require constant reiteration because the games are, at their core, simple - all the rules have already been fleshed out because the games have existed for hundreds of years. League has been out for like 6 years, and has a much more complex system of play in place, so of course they'll require constant reiteration (especially because a new soccer player doesn't change the competitive landscape of the game half as much as a new champion has the potential to.)

One fairly major difference is that sports don't really suffer from balance issues because they are inherently a level playing field (they even solved red side/blue side imbalance by switching sides at half).

Also with League, stagnation is similar to if the best way to win at baseball was to bunt every single hit. If no other strategy was as effective as bunting all the time then the game would be boring because every player on every team would play the same. It would be fair but uninteresting to watch. League suffers greatly from oftentimes having a single winning strategy and the winners are the ones who can adapt and abuse that strategy best. To counter this Riot keeps changing the game, not only keeping things interesting by forcing players to keep adapting, but to try to reach a point at which all the strategies they want to be used are viable at the same time.

But innovation for the pure sake of innovation can be detrimental.

Look at the WiiU's touchpad tea-tray sized controller, it was a solution looking for a problem and ultimately shot the console in the foot (I'm not pinning the WiiU's lackuster performance entirely on the controller, but the point is there). It was innovation for innvoation's sake. 

All I'm saying is, misplaced innovation can kill. And Riot needs to be careful about how they "innovate".

</cynicism>

That aside, you are right regardless.

League wasn't innovative in the first place. 

It was a quirky MOBA with snappy controls. That's all it was in the beginning. 

The laning phase is what got this game notoriety, but Riot's diminished laning phase significantly over the years.

At this point, League is popular just because its popular. It doesn't have anything over the other decent MOBAs, as a game now, outside of its popularity. Hell, parts of the community make it worse. 

You can downvote me all you like, but it doesn't change that League is feeling less and less like League, and more and more generic due to the changes they're making.

If League had remained in the same state as it was on launch, the game would be dead. Not for lack of new content, but because its flawed structure, limited tech and imperfect design would have eventually caused players to lose hope in seeing it fulfill its potential. The changes made to the game over time aren't perfect either (some have been flat-out terrible), but they're leading it towards a direction where it can continue to grow and fine-tune the experience it offers. It's difficult to realize this here, on the Gameplay Boards, which are mostly populated by hyperbolic complaint threads based on the most recent state of the game's balance, but League has become a significantly better game over time. Even though there are problems now, they're far less severe than the game's problems in the previous seasons (e.g. permaban Kassadin, assassins with silences, entire subclasses of champions being near-unplayable, etc.), and the changes you mentioned have significantly improved League's design over time.

Because Riot learned from Starcraft. That was the first major worldwide e-sport. After 5 years or so the game became robotic because people figured out the formula. Players became less human and more machine. It became less about split second decisions and more about how perfect your macro game was.

Riot didn't want that for league, so they keep changing things so no one can ever figure out the formula. It's a risky proposition because they risk alienating their player base but it's necessary to keep the game vibrant and constantly evolving.

League of Legends is balanced and maintained by constant a frequent changes that catapult different champions, builds, team compositions, and in game decisions.

It's held in place by having consistent and timeless basis that doesn't change even after years of being away, the game looks very much the same and is still approachable.

These two together, keep players from leaving out of boredom, and welcome players back who took a break for some reason easily.

Comparatively, DotA is significantly more *balanced* but rarely ever changes anything but the most minor tweaks.  It was one of the most popular games back as a WC3 Mod, but has barely changed since then resulting in only the more die-hard player base and struggling to keep a casual crowd who enjoy new and exciting things to play often.

You can chance a ton of numbers, but some champions/mechanics/items will stay inherently toxic so that they have to either be very bad in 99% of the cases or abusable. Although I have often disagreed on details, I tend to like Riot's philosophy more than any other gaming company that I have experience with.

> "If it ain't broke, don't fix it."

But when has is not been broke, according to some faction of players? People have, and always will, find something to complain about.

On the contrary, I've never found anything much worth complaining about.

Changing the game keeps it fresh

It's almost impossible to achieve balance in a game like LoL, the next best thing Riot can do is rotate the metas so at least the game feels fresh. 

Admittedly Riot's changes lately have been increasingly more troll, but the absolute worst thing they can do is become Blizzard 2.0 where they just let 1 stale ass meta sit around for half a year before doing anything about it.

When things stop changing, they die.
Lol is moba and with major flaws that makes its impossible to balance for good.
Few champions would become the only played at every elo, most champion would be consider trollpick or only counter. The perfect strategy will be found and everything will become boring and repetitive. Changes are needed to both keep players insterested and to improve the game.

One reason that has been noted by one or two Reds over the years is that in the beginning Riot didn't know what direction they wanted to take League of Legends.  They now have a goal for the kind of game they want to make it into.  Since then they have been pushing towards this goal.  A second reason is that Riot is always trying to mix things up and keep them fresh and new and crazy.  Small changes only do so much to accomplish this.  With larger scale changes, you can keep things a lot fresher than with small changes.  One item that will help with this is the Rotating Game mode, if Riot could come out with more ideas like this that mixes up the formula on a regular basis, then they would be pretty heavily set for quite some time.
